VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
During the renewal period there were three special investigations.
2017C0220013 4/11/17
It was reported to this consultant by the agency that a resident complained he was
physically managed in an aggressive manner. The resident admitted a history of
restraints for aggressive behavior toward staff and peers as well as not following
directions. This was confirmed by reviewing resident A.s history of seclusions and
restraints over the last twelve months. Staff reported that during snack on 3/11/17 the
resident was acting in a hostile and threatening manner toward another resident. Staff
made the decision to restrain the resident to prevent him from assaulting another
youth. The restraint resulted in both the staff and resident falling to the floor. This
consultant determined the staff’s restraint was justified in order to avoid a probable
assault by resident. There were no citations issued.
2017CO220020 8/10/17
The complainant alleged that the resident did not receive mental services. It was
documented between the detention record and medical record that the resident was
evaluated by a psychiatrist who recommended medication changes. The mother
refused to sign a consent for the medications. The psychiatrist removed the youth
4

from his rotation. The mother was provided with a referral to a community based
psychiatrist for follow up services. The resident was assigned to a therapist at
Children’s Village. The complainant also alleged that the resident was in room with
another resident she often fought with. It was confirmed that the resident was placed
in her own bedroom. The allegations were not substantiated. There were no citations
issued.
2017C0220022 9/6/17
It was alleged that a resident was intentionally injured during a restraint. This complaint
was jointly investigated with another DHHS unit. The resident told investigators that he
received marks when staff banged his head on the cement slab in the behavior
management room. According to resident he was not resisting staff. The two staff that
conducted the restraint and the one staff that witnessed the restraint stated the resident
resisted the transport. Staff stated the escort to the behavior management room and the
placement in the room followed protocol. Staff stated the placement in the BMR in front
of the cement was done quickly. Staff concluded the abrasions were the result of the
youth moving his head from side to side on the cement slab. This consultant and the
other DHHS consultant found no evidence that staff intentionally injured the resident
during the escort or during the placement in the BMR. The allegations were not
substantiated.
Interim Inspection 4/19/17
There was an annual inspection completed on 4/19/17. This inspection found the
agency compliant with all applicable licensing statutes and rules.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the facility be issued a renewal of their
regular license.
